'Philip IV of Spain' (; 8 April 1605 â 17 September 1665) was King of Spain (as
Philip IV in Castille and Philip III in Aragon) and Portugal as (). He ascended
the thrones in 1621 and reigned in Spain until his death and in Portugal until
1640. Philip is remembered for his patronage of the arts, including such artists
as Diego VelÃ¡zquez, and his rule over Spain during the challenging period of the
Thirty Years' War.

On the eve of his death in 1665, the Spanish Empire had reached a then-unheard-
of but in other respects was in decline, a process to which Philip's inability
to achieve successful domestic and military reform is felt to have contributed.
